Description.val: This system is formally specified by both Fleet Commanders as a threshold capability for global maritime command control and communications in a Distributed Maritime Environment to execute current warfighting plans and is required for National Command and Control capability. Funding provides for the procurement and installation of Integrated Waveform (IW) and Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) Digital Modular Radio (DMR) systems and IW and MUOS upgrade kits.  DMR with IW and MUOS hardware is a four-channel software defined radio that provides satellite communications, Line of Sight (LOS) and High Frequency (HF), Very High Frequency (VHF) and Ultra High Frequency (UHF) communication capability to surface, submarine, and shore facilities.  This variant of the DMR, including upgrade kits, provides hardware with IW/MUOS capability.

Justification.val:
The FY2020 funding request was reduced by $5.473 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances. 

FY 2020 funding provides for the procurement of 18 DMR IW & MUOS systems and 11 DMR IW & MUOS upgrade kits. In addition, FY 2020 includes funding to implement cybersecurity upgrades and cryptographic modernization to increase system performance and security for fielded DMRs.

Name.val: 2.1) DMR IW and MUOS System Production Support

Name.@footnote: DSA estimates are based off a percentage of the total installation cost with 75% of costs being required the year prior for installation design work and 25% required the year of the actual installation.  The DSA cost variance is due to ship configuration being installed.  The DSA decrease from FY 2019 to FY 2020 is a result of the decrease in the number of installations planned: 10 installations in FY 2020 to 6 installations in FY 2021.
Name.val: 2.2) DMR IW and MUOS System DSA
1.1.1) DMR IW and MUOS System Procurement - Shore - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: The combination of configurations purchased in FY 2020 gives the appearance of an average unit cost increase. FY20 is procuring 1 more big deck (LCC/LHD/CVN) systems than in FY19 ($4.142M/system), 1 more LSD class system ($1.324M/system), 6 more DDG system ($1.392M/system), 3 more USCG systems ($1.392M/system), and 1 less submarine system ($0.687M/system). Large-deck platforms require 3 DMR radios and more associated ancillary equipment, compared to 1 DMR radio for all other configurations.
Name.val: 1.1.2) DMR IW and MUOS System Procurement - Afloat - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: DMR IW and MUOS System Procurement - Shore
[none specified]:: Installation Name: DMR IW and MUOS System Procurement - Afloat

Description.val:
Integrated Waveform (IW) and Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) Digital Modular Radio (DMR) Systems. Quantities between radios and kits may change from year to year as a result of ship availabilities and fleet priority.

[DMR IW and MUOS System Procurement - Afloat] FY 2020 funding provides for eighteen (18 QTY) DMR IW & MUOS afloat systems. 

DMR IW & MUOS system annual unit cost variances for procurements and installations are driven by system configurations. There are 3 different DMR IW & MUOS System afloat configurations (2 surface & 1 subsurface) and 5 different DMR IW & MUOS Upgrade Kit afloat configurations (3 surface & 2 subsurface). Additionally, shore sites do not have a standard configuration and are unique to each individual shore site. For shore, the budget reflects individual radios vice afloat configurations.  

For the DMR IW & MUOS System, the configuration ranges from 1 - 3 DMR radios and requires a unique set of ancillary equipment dependent upon ship class (racks, power amplifiers & antenna upgrades). For example, a CVN requires 3 DMR radios and would need 4 racks to complete installation. When compared to a small ship such as LCS, which needs only 1 DMR radio and 2 racks to complete installation. One (1) DMR system will range in cost depending on the type of configuration and Economic Order Quantity Pricing relevant at time of contract award.

The nineteen (19) month Production Lead Time (PLT) for DMR System delivery is due to varying PLT's from multiple ancillary equipment vendors that are then integrated into the final product. Ancillary equipment is provided to SPAWAR Systems Center (SSC) Pacific for integration, assembly and test. The seven (7) month Administrative Lead Time (ALT) for DMR System procurements allows for the identification and receipt of other customer funds in order to take advantage of favorable quantity pricing.

ModificationTitle.val: (DN 111) DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits

Name.val: 2.1) DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits Production Support

Name.@footnote: DSA estimates are based off a percentage of the total installation cost with 75% of costs being required the year prior for installation design work and 25% required the year of the actual installation.  The DSA cost variance is due to ship configuration being installed.  The DSA increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 is a result of the increase in the number of installations planned: 10 installations in FY 2020 to 24 installations in FY 2021.
Name.val: 2.2) DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits DSA

Title.val: (DN 111) DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits

Name.@footnote: Unit Cost variances for procurements are driven by afloat upgrade kit configurations and ancillary equipment (racks, power amplifiers & antenna upgrades), which is dependent upon ship class. There are 5 different DMR IW & MUOS Upgrade Kit afloat configurations (3 surface & 2 subsurface) where each configuration ranges from 1 - 3 DMR upgrade kits and a unique set of ancillary equipment.
Name.val: 1.1.1) DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits Procurement - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) are required to implement cybersecurity upgrades and cryptographic modernization to increase system performance and security for fielded Digital Modular Radios (DMRs).  FY 2018-2020 procures and installs Win 10 upgrades and performs associated integration, assembly and test. FY 2018-2022 includes engineering changes associated with cryptographic modernization as directed by National Security Agency (NSA). DMRs current embedded cryptographic systems will no longer be able to communicate securely after Crypto Keys expire due to cease key dates as directed by NSA. In order to ensure warfighters continued secure (i.e. encrypted) communications, DMRs must modernize their cryptographic capabilities by implementing the latest algorithms.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method:: Installation Name: DMR MUOS Upgrade Kits

Description.val:
This system is formally specified by both Fleet Commanders as a threshold capability for global maritime command control and communications in a Distributed Maritime Environment to execute current warfighting plans and is required for National Command and Control capability. Integrated Waveform (IW) and Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) Digital Modular Radio (DMR) Upgrade Kits. Quantities between radios and kits may change from year to year as a result of ship availabilities and fleet priority.

[DMR IW and MUOS Upgrade Kits Procurement] FY 2020 funding provides for eleven (11 QTY) DMR IW & MUOS afloat upgrade kits. In addition, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) are required to implement cybersecurity upgrades and cryptographic modernization to increase system performance and security for fielded Digital Modular Radios (DMRs).  

DMR IW & MUOS upgrade kit annual unit cost variances for procurements and installations are driven by system configurations. There are 3 different DMR IW & MUOS System afloat configurations (2 surface & 1 subsurface) and 5 different DMR IW & MUOS Upgrade Kit afloat configurations (3 surface & 2 subsurface). Additionally, shore sites do not have a standard configuration and are unique to each individual shore site. For shore, the budget reflects individual radios vice afloat configurations. 

For the DMR IW & MUOS Upgrade Kit, the configuration ranges from 1 - 3 DMR upgrade kits and requires a unique set of ancillary equipment dependent upon ship class (racks, power amplifiers & antenna upgrades).  DMR upgrade kit cost will vary depending on the type of configuration and Economic Order Quantity Pricing relevant at time of contract award.

The nineteen (19) month Production Lead Time (PLT) for DMR Upgrade Kit delivery is due to varying PLT's from multiple ancillary equipment vendors that are then integrated into the final product. Ancillary equipment is provided to SPAWAR Systems Center (SSC) Pacific for integration, assembly and test. The seven (7) month Administrative Lead Time (ALT) for DMR Upgrade Kit procurements allows for the identification and receipt of other customer funds in order to take advantage of favorable quantity pricing.
